meanings.definition: To diminish or destroy the quality or value of something.
meanings.sent1: Leaving food out in the sun can spoil it quickly.
meanings.sent2: Leaving milk out of the fridge can spoil it.
meanings.sent3: I forgot to put the fruit in the fridge, and now it's starting to spoil!
meanings.sent4: Her negative attitude can spoil the mood of the whole group.
meanings.sent5: The rain threatened to spoil our picnic plans.

meanings.definition: To harm the character or nature of someone.
meanings.sent1: Being around negative people can spoil your mood.
meanings.sent3: His mischievous grin hinted that he was up to spoil some fun.
meanings.sent4: The lies began to spoil the trust between them.
meanings.sent5: One bad experience shouldn't spoil your view of the world.

meanings.definition: Goods stolen or taken forcibly from a person or place.
meanings.sent1: The pirates celebrated their spoils from the raid.
meanings.sent2: The thieves divided the spoils of their heist.
meanings.sent3: The cat proudly presented its spoil of a mouse to its owner.
meanings.sent4: The spoils of war were displayed in the museum.
meanings.sent5: The treasure hunters were excited to find ancient spoils in the cave.
